ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Q10: This class is valuable for students with an interest in climate policy and students who wish to do a lot of policy analysis and memo writing.
It was a useful class. Valuable to hear Dan's perspectives on how things happen or happened in DC, which is where I think he added most value.

I would definitely recommend this course to other students (if only Dan were teaching it again!). The class was well-structured--it started off a bit slower in the beginning and then progressed at a good pace later on. The problem set was actually quite useful for my learning, but it would have been nice to have had an extra week to complete it. Also, the guest speakers were interesting, and Dan made a serious effort to steer the topics of the class toward the interests of the students.

Dan was an excellent Professor. I learned a significant amount from him. Unlike many other practitioners is class was NOT story time with Dan, and that is a good thing. Sometimes Dan was almost too knowledgable. He would often zoom passed my understanding on issues.
The opportunity to write extensively on climate policy history and future solutions.
Problem set was challenging and time intensive but useful.
Dan's vast understanding on the material.
Dan Lashof is great! He's extremely knowledgable, and very approachable. No other classes dealing with this course material, which is a shame that he was only here for one semester.

During the semester, this was definitely my most challenging class. I often felt I was just doing my best to keep my head above water, but by the end of the semester I was surprised at how much more I understand about the key pieces of climate policy. I think the biggest realization of this happened in giving my presentation to the class. I now certainly appreciate the challenge of this class and how it allowed me to understand, and potentially participate in a sophisticated debate about climate policy (e.g. discussing price collars and floors, the pros and cons of offsets, whether the US is living up to its international commitments etc.)

The insight of an experienced practitioner like yourself, the struggle of dealing with that problem set and satisfaction that came with completion, guest lecturers, and the off-the-cuff or ultra-current anecdotal material you brought to the table.
Professor has excellent experience and great anecdotal stories. Really put the course materials into context!
When we had discussions and Dan shared his personal experiences -- wish there was more of that.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: More preparation for the problem set would have been helpful to enhance the learning experience.
Finding ways to get students to participate more. This is difficult sometimes but not impossible. It helped that student presentations were given in last few classes, as this engaged us pretty well.

The one thing that I did not like was the last minute change to the syllabus to have student-led discussions. While I don't mind the student-led discussions, further advance notice would have been very helpful with all of the other things going on at the end of the semester.

I thought we spent a little too much time on W/M bill. It's a watershed bill and it showed us the a path toward comprehensive climate bill, but I felt like we could have moved through it a bit faster. The student presentations were interesting and perhaps it would have been better to organize them a bit sooner in the future.

Dan's lectures are a bit arcane. Would be good to start the first 10 minutes with a very basic overview (no powerpoint, or minimal powerpoint) of the class topic, and then get into the details. Important to have the in depth knowledge, but sometimes its easy to get lost without a bigger picture.

I felt as though the class was quite reticent in discussions for the first part of the semester, so I wonder if having student run classes earlier in the semester would be a good way to have people get more comfortable in class. In particular, I think it would be beneficial to have the students run classes dedicated to going through the details of the Waxman-Markey Bill. This would likely force students to dig into that material a bit more and have students visit office hours prior to the class they have been assigned to present.I felt that the problem set was way above my abilities, but also incredibly beneficial to learn. In the future, I think it would work better to have the same problem set assigned to us broken into three separate problem sets (one for each question). This would make the problem set more manageable, and allow for a learning curve. (Even if a student bombs the first problem set, they still have time to recover and feel they have developed the skill for searching for the appropriate data and more fully understanding the calculations.)

The course covers an important topic, but from a teaching perspective it has a handicap in being a topic with limited history. So I would image that is restrictive on some level. In order to help work around this aspect, which I think indirectly affects student opinion about class while going through it, my suggestions are as follows:1.) I'm glad I was exposed to bills and international agreements, but I think reading less Waxman-Markey and others would be ideal if the point is to have discussion based on those readings. I'm sure others can do this, but I struggled to have discussion points to bring to class based off those readings, so perhaps less of those and a few more readings with perspective or commentary on those bills might spark better discussion.2.) I liked the guest lecturers. Having a couple more to add might be a nice way to bring in multiple perspectives/discussion approaches when the topic itself is one that has its limits in terms of the history.3.) Maybe another week or two of global happenings could be interesting since it felt like we'd exhausted the US case a bit by the end (even though I'm sure we hadn't; just for variety's sake).4.) Refine the last group work yo had us do: I liked the last class lecture you gave, and I wonder in a sense if it could be the starting class, or come up sooner, and from that point onwards we think of the class and one group exercise to follow as a sort of lab inexploring new ideas. I know that our class presentations sort of do this but a group paper or lecture announced from the outset as one exercise where we're supposed to think of it as really lab-y and experimental, that we show you in advance so that you can provide suggestions on what kind of support material might be best, etc, could be a neat way to break free from disappointment of what's happened to date on this topic, and a way to take the optimsism of your last lecture and try to run with it.
Class discussion was more difficult since many people were new to this topic.
Could sometimes get too detailed and too specific into the bills. Instead of talking about what didn't work, I would have liked to spend more time talking about a path forward.

Daniel Lashof is a very knowledgeable and personable instructor but some of the lectures were a bit dry. He brought in a guest lecturer that was a nice change of pace, but perhaps finding a different method to cover close readings of legislative texts would be good. The class has a broad range so I would still recommend it.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Very responsive to questions.
They were responsive to my comments/questions.
Dan was very available.
Great! Dan was very accessible and helpful in office hours or after class on the problem set and guidance for paper topics.
I met with both the TA and the instructor outside of class and both were very happy to make time for me and spend plenty of time helping me to understand class concepts and think about paper ideas.
Very responsive (both).
Great comments on papers.
Good. Instructor available for office hours and TA responsive to email / making comments on papers.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: First class that really focused on the U.S. policy context. Very essential to my anticipated work in developing federal climate legislation.
As an energy policy focused student, material was very relevant to issues affecting energy supply.
Super relevant to my interests.
I study climate diplomacy and this course was essential for my studies. It did not disappoint.
Focused on climate change, so understanding US climate policy is integral.
I felt that this class was very helpful in allowing me to narrow down the focus of my masters program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Chance to better understand the dynamics of US Climate policy debate, read the details of the legislation, and have numerous opportunities to write policy memos.
Wanted to learn about climate policy and hear Dan's account of things.

It is relevant to my interests and future career. It is unfortunate for FES that it was a one semester deal; I feel fortunate that I was able to take it when it was offered. I think that the course was not well advertised, though, or many other students might have enrolled. I found out about it only at the course expo.
To take a course on US climate policy taught be a well-known and well-respected expert. Dan did a great job!
I took this course because I wanted to learn the recent history of US climate change policy from someone who has been working behind closed doors on the issues.
Wanted to fill in knowledge gaps before graduating.
Interest in policy

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes, mostly. I would have liked to spend more time writing policy memos and to have my drafts critiqued by fellow students, the TA, and professor, before finalizing the memos. This would have enhanced the learning and made the class more interactive.Also, while we discussed anecdotal legislative dynamics, we did not discuss much theory on how the U.S. congress or presidency plays a role in policy creation. It may have been useful to develop this theoretical training more to talk about U.S. policy debate.
Yes.
Yes.
Exceeded my expectations.
Yes, was an excellent overview of climate policy and still went in depth into topics.
Getting Dan Lashof's impressions of climate policy development and barriers to implementation was very interesting.
Yes. I learned a LOT.
Yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
Yes.
Yes and more.

It was very interesting getting to hear Dan Lashof's perspective on developments and failures in implementation of US climate policy.I have found that every class at F&ES expects a lot from students, and, unfortunately, without hard deadlines and problem sets it is too easy for a class to be put on the back burner. I would suggest potentially more problem sets based on the readings to ensure more in-depth discussions. I might re-arrange the work in the class to look more like: More frequent problem sets (Ive found students resent classeswith weekly problem sets). When they are not quantitative problem sets, a simple set of questions based on key points from the reading would be useful (and make that problem set due the day of that discussion). One round of student-led classes early in the semester, in addition to student presentations at the end of the semester. With the other added work, it might make sense to have only one midterm paper and one final paper.
Yes.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Group work was good chance to challenge each other's views of clean energy policy and debate merits of policy solutions.
Interesting to share perspectives amongst students.
The main advantages of group work in this class is that they made everyone more comfortable and made class discussions more lively.
I like to do group work but, as discussed above, would like to see it refined to be more ambitious than it was.
Great opportunity to talk about our paper topics, which was helpful for final paper-writing.

Nice to give a group presentation and meet out of class with fellow students, but hard to schedule meetings and prepare for this right on top of finals. I would suggest doing these earlier in the course.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Stay up to date with the national climate policy debate while taking the class and bring topics in the news to class.
Given heavy emphasis on papers, it's really on you to go out and learn about the topics.

I hope we invite Dan back to FES. He would be a wonderful addition to our faculty. I would suggest that they get to know W/M and realize that Dan has a grasp on almost every aspect of US climate policy.

This class will provide you with a great real-world perspective on US Climate policy, but it is very challenging. A student might benefit from this class more if they have already taken a class in or had some background in energy policy (ie. what changes power plants can make to be more efficient etc.)
Ask questions and try to engage in discussion
